attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
Findings. 
•    A physical stock count was conducted on 3rd June 2025 to verify inventory accuracy by comparing physical stock balances with the stock balances from the SAP system and assessing the effectiveness of internal stock controls.
•    A few discrepancies in the inventory records were observed as illustrated below:
i.    Bread stock had a deficit  of 73.5 Loaves,
ii.    Polybags had a surplus of 2,042 pieces,
iii.    White flour had a deficit of 6.7kgs,
iv.    Wheat bran had a deficit of 6.03kgs,
v.    Brown flour had a negative variance of 2.68kgs,
vi.    Utto had a negative variance of 1.77 litres,
vii.    Other stock items had minimal variation as illustrated below;
 

Crates Movement.
•    A physical count of crates at the branch was conducted to assess the effectiveness of crate movement controls.
•    The results indicated that there were opening balance amounting to 313 crates and had crates amounting to 111 which were in excess and yet to be transferred to ingredients.
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch management should ensure that the actual number of loaves salvaged is recorded daily and compared against 2% of total production for that day
•    For polybags, branch management should consider implementing a daily polybag usage record in production with a reconciliation process against bread output and damaged polybags in order to trace accurately the ever noted positive variance at the branch
attributes.effect:
•    The identified discrepancies suggest that stock management and recording processes need improvement.
•     The variances, though not major in all cases, point to potential gaps in internal controls and tracking systems for both inventory and crate movement.
•    Inconsistent stock records increase the risk of undetected loss, pilferage, or spoilage. Over time, such variances could accumulate to a material loss if unaddressed.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Variances in bread, polybags, and ingredients.
Remediation Plan:

  • Implement daily stock recording and reconciliation.
  • Monitor salvaged bread and polybag usage closely.
  • Strengthen physical stock count procedures and system updates.

Issue: Excess 111 crates not yet transferred to ingredients department.
Remediation Plan:

  • Reconcile crate movement and ensure the excess crates are transferred.

value:
•    We shall strengthen the stock controls to minimize the branch variances noted.
•    We will ensure that all stock items are recorded accurately in the system. This will help reduce any differences between the actual stock and what is recorded, minimizing stock variances.
•    The current difference in bread stock is partly due to some salvaging. Once the oven is fully working, this should help reduce the variance even more.

•    Control is being maintained by conducting regular stock counts.
•    The issuance of polybags did not match the physical stock.
•    We are following up on the crates issue to ensure it is resolved.

•    In the prior audit report dated 17th   April 2025 stock take reveled the following:
    Polybags +3,726 Pieces.
    Bread stock had a negative variance of 5 Loaves.
    White flour had a variance of -6Kgs.
    Wheat Bran had a variation of +7.
    Brown flour had a variance of -7kgs,
    All other materials had negligible variations.
    Crates had nil variance.
Previous

Minor discrepancies were noted in several stock items, suggesting weaknesses in stock tracking and documentation. Although not material individually, these variances point to systemic control gaps that may lead to cumulative losses if not addressed.
Operations/Production Department
To verify the accuracy of inventory records by comparing physical stock counts with SAP system data and evaluating the effectiveness of internal stock and crate movement controls.

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
•    An analysis of both mixing chart and mixing chart summary was done for a period of 31 days from 1st May 2025 to 31st May 2025.
•    This analysis aimed to assess whether the average yield per production bag and actual Utto consumption aligned with the set BOM, evaluate the full utilization of branch production capacity and ensure compliance with quality standards.
•    The analysis revealed the following:
i.    Utto consumption stood at 100%.
ii.    The average yield was 190.54 loaves per bag.
iii.    Average production was 73.65 bags per day, this represents 90.92% of the set target of 81 bags.
iv.    There were 90 remixes for the period audited.
•    Below is a summary of the audit finding:
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch management should liaise with KAF in order to implement a preventive maintenance schedule for critical equipment like the oven to reduce unexpected breakdowns.
•    Branch management should also ensure production strictly follows the standard BOM to avoid variances in output
attributes.effect:
•    The branch achieved only 90.92% of the set daily production target (73.65 bags vs. 81 bags), indicating that the branch is operating below optimal capacity.
•    The frequent oven breakdowns are directly affecting the branch’s ability to meet production targets, leading to reliance on inter-branch transfers, which increases logistics complexity and may compromise freshness, quality issues and or consistency.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Underutilization of capacity (only 90.92% achieved), high remix cases.
Remediation Plan:

  • Introduce preventive maintenance for ovens.

  • Enforce strict adherence to Bill of Materials (BOM).

  • Monitor production capacity versus actual output monthly

value:
•    The main challenge preventing us from reaching our target was the frequent breakdown of the oven.
•    We relied on transfers from other branches in order to satisfy our sales.
•    Future branch expansions are expected to rely on our branch's production capacity
•    Production target are not achieved due bread balance control as per sales order.

•    In Prior Audit, audit findings were as follows: 
        Average production was 73.74 bags equivalent to 91.02% of the set target of 81 bags.
        Utto units consumption to bags of flour ratio was 1:1
         The average yield was 190.67 loaves per bag.
          There were 1,406 cases of remixes for the period.
Previous

A full-month review of production mixing charts for May 2025 was performed. The analysis focused on daily production capacity, ingredient consumption (particularly Utto), and consistency in yield per production bag to determine compliance with operational targets.

Production yield was close to expectations; however, the branch operated at only 90.92% of capacity. Frequent oven breakdowns impacted output and caused remixing inefficiencies. Preventive maintenance and strict BOM adherence are critical for improvement.
Operations/Production Department
To assess production efficiency by evaluating yield per bag, ingredient usage, remix frequency, and adherence to the Bill of Materials (BOM).

attributes.title: Cash Verification.
attributes.description:
•    As part of our routine checks, a cash verification was carried out to confirm that the physical cash on hand matched the recorded cash balance in the cash flow records. This was also intended to assess the effectiveness of cash handling and management controls.
•    It was noted that a negative balance of Ksh 1,200 occurred due to a payment issued earlier that morning to Chepkwany for tyre repair, for which the corresponding receipt had not yet been submitted as detailed below.
attributes.recommendation:
•    All staff should be required to submit receipts or support documents immediately after any cash disbursement. In cases where this is not possible documentation should be submitted within the same day.
•    Branch management should maintain the existing cash control.
attributes.effect: •    Cash management controls are generally effective, with only a minor variance of Ksh 1,201, which is traceable to a same-day payment for tyre repair.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Minor cash variance (Ksh 1,201) due to undocumented tyre repair.
Remediation Plan:

  • Require immediate submission of receipts after cash disbursement.

  • Use a cash voucher log to track all cash expenses until supporting documents are submitted.

value: •    Controls are generally effective we shall always keep close monitoring

•    Cashier had been advised for creating written record for all kind of cash out (Expenses).
•    Looking for rectification.

•    In prior audit, there was nil variance between cashflow amount and cash at hand.
•    However, there were two pending IOus, of Ksh.7,000.00. (Albert Okoth date 22.03.25 for meals, Ramadhan Ksh.5,000.00 for construction site inspection)
A cash verification exercise was conducted on 4th June 2025. The aim was to confirm that all cash receipts and payments were properly recorded and that physical cash tallied with system records.

A minor variance of Ksh 1,201 was found, which was traceable to a tyre repair expense pending documentation. Overall, cash controls are working effectively, with room for improvement in timely support documentation.
Operations/Production Department
To confirm that the cash held physically at the branch is in line with recorded balances and to assess the effectiveness of cash handling practices.

attributes.title: Bread weight analysis.
attributes.description:
•    A spot check on the weights of packed bread ready to be dispatched to the market was conducted on 3rd June 2025 to verify if the bread weight was compliant with the KEBS standard weight.
•    The results showed mixed compliance across different bread varieties:
i.    The 1.5kg bread samples were uniformly underweight, with 100% of samples falling below the standard weight.
ii.    Other varieties such as 800g Brown, 600g Naivas and 600g Brown had a majority of samples within the correct weight range, though there were notable percentages of both overweight and underweight samples.
iii.    Several varieties, including 400g bread, showed a high proportion of underweight samples, with some batches having over 70% of loaves below the standard weight.
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch management is recommended to ensure regular calibration of weighing machines to facilitate standard weight achievement.
•    Adjustments may be required to maintain standard weight especially under current oven limitations for bread varieties 1.5kg and 800g.
attributes.effect:
•    Regular distribution of underweight products can lead to customer complaints, loss of trust and damage to the brand’s image especially for major client such as Naivas something that cannot be risked given the competitive nature of the market.
•    Overweight loaves may result in excess ingredient use, increasing production costs unnecessarily or even affecting other variety weight directly
•    Failure to meet KEBS weight standards could lead to regulatory penalties, reputational damage, and potential financial losses.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: High rates of underweight loaves, particularly 1.5kg and 800g.
Remediation Plan:

  • Calibrate weighing machines regularly.

  • Adjust production processes to ensure weights meet  standards.

  • Replace old ovens contributing to uneven baking and weight inconsistencies.

value:
•    The major issue at the branch is the fact that Oven takes more baking time than required especially for 1.5kg and 800g bread categories.
•    There is a plan to introduce new ovens at the branch to facilitate our production and weight standard attainment.

•    The production procedure will be strictly followed, including dividing product ranges by variety.
•    The required number of tins shall be maintained in rotation according to the production plan.
Previous

A spot check was conducted on 3rd June 2025 to assess whether packed bread destined for the market met the required weight specifications. Samples across different product categories were tested for compliance.

Several underweight samples, especially the 1.5kg and 400g categories, were noted. The inconsistencies can result in customer dissatisfaction and regulatory issues. Immediate calibration and process adjustments are necessary.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure that all bread varieties meet the standard weight requirements as per KEBS guidelines and internal quality policies.

attributes.title: Bread damages Percentage Analysis
attributes.description:
•    An in-depth analysis was conducted to assess the levels of bread damage arising from both production defects and market-related issues during the period from 1st May 2025 to 31st May 2025. The objective was to determine whether the branch was adhering to the established quality control standards.
•    We noted the following:
I.    Bread damages occurring during production amounted to 0.21% of the total production volume, which is slightly above the acceptable KPI limit of 0.20%. Although the deviation is minor, it indicates a need for closer monitoring of production processes to prevent further deterioration in quality.
II.    Market-related damages, which include deformities or issues identified at the market level stood at 0.78% of total sales. This is significantly higher than the KPI threshold of 0.50% pointing to potential weaknesses in areas such as post-production handling, transportation, stock rotation at retail outlets, or inadequate quality checks during dispatch as demonstrated in the table below:
 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

NB. Oven-related damages (435 loaves) were excluded from the analysis.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Supermarket Return Analysis

   • This test was conducted to analyze bread returns from various supermarket outlets, with the aim of identifying the primary reasons for returns and determining which supermarkets contributed the most to total returns.
•    Naivas Ltd and Quickmart Ltd had highest returns in the branch and various returns reasons are as highlighted below:
I.    Expired and Short Expiry Bread was the leading cause, indicating potential issues with inventory rotation, forecasting, or poor control from merchandisers. 
II.    Instances of Ordered but Not Delivered were observed during the period, primarily due to the branch lacking sufficient stock to meet demand and relying on inter-branch transfers.
III.    Torn Wrappers and Quality-related returns were noted in a few instances, indicating potential gaps in final product inspection or mishandling during transit. 
Implication:
•    High returns from major supermarkets like Naivas and Quickmart mainly due to expired bread, missed deliveries and packaging problems show weaknesses in stock forecasting, delivery planning and coordination issues.
•    Market damages stood at 0.78%, well above the KPI target of 0.50%, resulting in a cost of Ksh 73,410.44. This highlights concerns around post-production handling, stock rotation at the retail level and quality checks during dispatch.

Damages sent to Ingredients’ Balance Analysis

•    An audit verification was carried out on 2nd June 2025 to confirm that all bread damages reported as transferred to the Ingredients Department were either physically present or properly recorded in accordance with established procedures.
•    The verification covered the period from 1st May 2025 to 31st May 2025. During the review, a discrepancy was identified between the expected and actual physical stock of damaged bread, as summarized below:
attributes.recommendation:
•    Merchandisers should be advised to align orders more closely with actual market demand to avoid overstocking and reduce expiry-related returns.
•    Supervisors should implement stricter checks at the packing stage to catch deformities or wrapper issues before dispatch.

•    Every instance of bread damage, including moldy disposed bread should be thoroughly recorded before disposal.
•    Oversight of damaged bread stock should be improved by ensuring reliable and consistent documentation, along with regular alignment of physical counts, manual records and system entries.
attributes.effect:
•    Moldy bread being disposed of without being properly recorded or sent to the Ingredients Department might lead to untraceable losses and loss of audit trial.
•    The discrepancy between recorded and actual physical balances indicates deficiencies in internal controls related to damage recording, transfers to the ingredients department and disposal tracking.
•    The procedures for documenting, monitoring, and transferring damaged bread were not consistently adhered to, thereby increasing the risk of data manipulation, product loss and unaccounted waste.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Production and market damages slightly above KPI limits.
Remediation Plan:

  • Strengthen post-production handling and quality checks.

  • Improve packaging and transport monitoring.

  • Align supermarket orders with demand to reduce expiry returns.

Issue: High returns due to expiry, short deliveries, and torn wrappers.
Remediation Plan:

  • Improve inventory rotation and forecasting.

  • Assign staff to perform final quality checks before dispatch.

  • Enhance communication between branches to prevent short deliveries.

Issue: Discrepancy of 233.2 kg (≈583 loaves) between reported and actual damages sent to ingredients
Remediation Plan:

  • Maintain a proper record of all damaged bread sent to ingredients.

  • Require physical count verification before recording any disposals.

  • Conduct regular reconciliations between system entries and physical stock.

value:
•    There were moldy bread disposed separately without being sent to ingredients.
•    Some instances of bread return at the branch which is good for resale ie fresh bread also appears in the system as return and which is not necessarily damage to be sent to ingredient.  
 •    We are currently operating within the acceptable range and are actively implementing measures to further reduce these damages.
•    We have controlled the market damages to 0.46% and due to supermarkets damages such as moldy bread disposed the percentage at the branch has increased to the noted percentage.
•    We shall continue ensuring our controls are in line to reduce all damages to the acceptable threshold.

•    We shall continue ensuring our controls are in line to reduce all damages to the acceptable threshold.

•    Managers are advised to properly record all damages to prevent discrepancies.
•    Appropriate control measures should be strengthened to ensure accuracy and accountability.

•    During the prior audit date 14th April 2025, it was noted that;      
    Production damages were 0.28% of the total production,
    Market damages were 0.89% of the total sales.
•    In the previous audit report, it was observed that there was a significant difference between total damage at the branch level and damage sent to ingredients damage. 
•    Total branch damage was 9,112.90 pieces while those sent to ingredients were 8,657.50 pieces, this impling that damages sent were less by 412.40 loaves.
Bread damages for May 2025 were analyzed to determine if they remained within the company’s acceptable thresholds. The audit distinguished between production damages and market returns.

Both production (0.21%) and market (0.78%) damages exceeded the respective KPI limits. Quality control and post-production handling need to be improved to reduce losses and enhance customer satisfaction.
To evaluate the level of bread wastage from production and the market, and measure performance against the set KPIs.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
•    An evaluation was carried out to determine how effectively human resources are being utilized in the production department, with emphasis on whether production staff are achieving the company’s benchmark of 4.5 production bags per worker, as specified in the operational policy.
•    The analysis revealed that production efficiency was at 4.29 per production worker, which was slightly below  the standard rate of 4.5 bags as seen in the summary below:
attributes.recommendation:
•    Implementation of a preventive maintenance schedule for production equipment, particularly ovens, to reduce downtime and avoid disruptions is necessary moving forward.
•    Branch management should also regularly review staffing levels based on actual production needs and historical efficiency data to prevent overstaffing and manage labor costs.
attributes.effect: •    Production efficiency fell short of the 4.5 bags per worker target, achieving only 4.29 bags. The shortfall indicates inefficient labor utilization and increased operational costs.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Average output per worker was 4.29 bags (below target of 4.5).
Remediation Plan:

  • Adjust staffing levels based on actual output.
  • Repair production equipment to avoid downtime.
  • Introduce incentive-based productivity tracking.

value:
•    There were production disruptions due to oven breakdowns, which significantly contributed to our failure to meet the target.
•    On ideal situation we shall try working closely to meet our targets
•    Production efficiency must be maintained, with continuous efforts to improve and achieve the required branch performance levels.
•    The previous audit report indicated a production efficiency of 4.33 bags per production worker.

An evaluation of staff efficiency in the production department was conducted for May 2025. The audit compared actual production figures against the number of workers employed and the company's performance target.

The branch achieved 4.29 bags per worker, slightly below the 4.5 target. Overstaffing was evident, and equipment issues such as oven breakdowns affected output. A review of staffing and equipment reliability is necessary.
Operations/Production Department
To measure how effectively human resources in the production section are being utilized in relation to the set output benchmark of 4.5 bags per worker.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency.
attributes.description:
•    An assessment was conducted to evaluate the efficiency of packers in the slicing section, aiming to determine if they met the company’s standard of 97 crates per packer.
•    The analysis covered a period of 31 days from 1st May 2025 to 31st May 2025   which revealed that the packing efficiency was 84.38 crates per packer which was slightly below the target as shown below:
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch management should adjust staffing levels based on actual performance data and review daily output to avoid unnecessary labor costs.
•    Supervisory oversight in the slicing section should be strengthened to ensure optimal performance and accountability.
attributes.effect:
•    The packing efficiency recorded at 84.38 crates per packer is slightly below the company’s target of 97 crates, indicating a marginal underperformance in packing productivity.
•    Continual inefficiencies may indicate issues such as lack of supervision, inadequate training, or workflow issues.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Slight underperformance (92.79 crates vs. target 97).
Remediation Plan:

  • Review packer performance daily and reassign where necessary.
  • Provide refresher training on packing techniques.
  • Monitor and reduce idle time in slicing section.

value: •    We shall do monitoring and follow up to ensure that the efficiency is attained

•    Procedures and controls are to be followed and consistently maintained.
•    It is also worth noting that the slicer team has shown an improvement in their efficiency.
•    The previous audit report indicated a packing efficiency of 80.81 crates per packer.
A review of packing operations during May 2025 was conducted to determine how efficiently the slicing team was operating and whether excess labor costs were being incurred due to underperformance.
The packing efficiency stood at 92.79 crates per packer, slightly below the target. Improved supervision and staff scheduling can help bridge this performance gap and avoid unnecessary costs.
Operations/Production Department
To assess whether packers in the slicing section meet the company’s performance standard of 97 crates per worker.

attributes.title: Mini shop
attributes.description:
•    A spot check was carried out at the Mini Shop on 4th June 2025, to confirm that all bread stocked for sale was accurately recorded and that the reported sales were fully reconciled with the collections made via the designated Mpesa pay bill number. The Mini Shop operates under a cashless policy.
•    The audit confirmed that bread stock and sales quantities were accurately recorded. The reconciliation of expected sales value (Kshs 22,933.0) with the adjusted Mpesa collections (Kshs 22,908.3) resulted in a minor variance of Kshs -24.70, which is within acceptable rounding and transaction cost limits. Below is a summary of the audit finding:
attributes.recommendation: •    The existing inventory and sales reconciliation procedures should be maintained, as they are effective in ensuring accuracy and transparency.
attributes.effect: •    The minor variance of Kshs -24.70 between expected sales and Mpesa collections is within acceptable limits and likely due to transaction costs. However, this needs to be monitored and minimized at all time
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Minor variance of Ksh -24.70 due to Mpesa transaction rounding.
Remediation Plan:

  • Continue existing reconciliation process.
  • Monitor digital payment consistency and charges.

value: •    Controls in place shall be maintained.
•    Controls in place shall be maintained.

A spot check was carried out at the Mini Shop on 4th June 2025 to verify that sales and collections were properly recorded. The focus was on accuracy, completeness, and reconciliation of sales with Mpesa payments.
A minimal variance of Ksh 24.70 was noted, likely due to transaction charges. The system is working well, but continued monitoring is recommended to maintain accuracy.
Operations/Production Department
To confirm that bread sales and Mpesa collections at the Mini Shop reconcile accurately and that the cashless operations are functioning as intended.

attributes.title: Vehicles Fuel Consumption Analysis.
attributes.description:
•    A review was conducted on the branch of vehicles’ fuel consumption to determine if there was optimal utilization of fuel for the month of May 2025
Finding:
•    Narok route vehicle KCW 425H had over-consumed by 38.46ltrs. The vehicle had breakdown for one day.
•    Olkalau route vehicle KDP 365L also had an overconsumption of 5.44ltrs and audit recommended the fuel to be utilized or deducted on the following day to prevent the balance from accumulating further.
•    Naivasha Town tuktuk KTWC 121V has a faulty mileage and therefore no mileage record.
•    Reliever route KCC 340Z had an overconsumption of 35.38ltrs but Has Issue with starter thus over consuming. There is a plan to reassign a new reliever
•    Other Route vehicle’s fuel consumption was within the set standard as detailed in below:


Implication:
•    Fuel inefficiencies were observed in several vehicles, leading to excess fuel consumption which may result in increased operational costs if not addressed.
•    Mechanical issues such as breakdowns and faulty starters are contributing to higher fuel consumption, indicating a need for timely vehicle maintenance and repairs.
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch management should prioritize fixing vehicles and TukTuks with mileage tracking issues to restore proper monitoring of fuel consumption.
•    Should also ensure that any overconsumption is either justified, utilized, or deducted from the following day's allocation to prevent balance buildup.
attributes.effect:
•    Fuel inefficiencies were observed in several vehicles, leading to excess fuel consumption which may result in increased operational costs if not addressed.
•    Mechanical issues such as breakdowns and faulty starters are contributing to higher fuel consumption, indicating a need for timely vehicle maintenance and repairs.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Overconsumption in 3 vehicles due to breakdowns or mechanical faults.
Remediation Plan:

  • Repair vehicles and faulty speedometers promptly.
  • Deduct unexplained overconsumption from the next day’s allocation.

Maintain accurate mileage logs for accountability.

value:
•    We shall continue issuing fuel according to kms covered.
•    Vehicles and TukTuk with speedometer issues we shall follow up to ensure they are resolved
•    We shall continue issuing fuel according to kms covered and this control shall be emphasized
•    During the previous audit it was noted that the actual fuel consumption for each vehicle was within the set standard except for KDK 287W which had an overconsumption.
Fuel usage records for all delivery routes in May 2025 were reviewed. The objective was to identify overconsumption, verify mileage reports, and evaluate vehicle maintenance needs.
Some vehicles recorded overconsumption due to mechanical issues such as faulty starters or speedometers. Prompt repairs and strict monitoring are needed to control fuel expenses.
Transport/Fleet Department
To assess whether the fuel used by branch vehicles aligns with actual mileage covered and to detect any inefficiencies or misuse.

attributes.title: Debtors’ Analysis.
attributes.description:
•    A review of the debtors’ balances as of 3rd June 2025 was conducted to determine if there were cases of outstanding balances at the branch that could result in bad debts.
•    It was noted that there were clients who had outstanding balances and therefore never supplied. There was also  a dormant account(institution) as illustrated  below
attributes.recommendation: •    The branch management and sales team should maintain strict debt management controls to prevent overdue balances from accumulating.
attributes.effect: •    Debt management within the branch is well controlled, with most customers having adequate security deposits.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Some overdue accounts and dormant clients.
Remediation Plan:

  • Maintain strict follow-up on all dormant and non performing clients.
  • Liaise with the sales team for collection updates.
  • Utilize security deposits for dormant accounts

value: •    We shall liaise with the sales team to ensure timely debt collection to facilitate supply.
•    Point taken for follow up and will keep on closely monitoring.
The audit examined outstanding balances as of 3rd June 2025. The goal was to evaluate credit management practices and highlight any dormant or risky debtor accounts.
Debt levels are generally well managed, with most accounts backed by security deposits. However, continuous follow-up and enforcement of collection procedures is recommended.
Sales Department
To review customer debt balances and ensure that overdue amounts are well controlled to minimize the risk of bad debts.

attributes.title: Generator Fuel Consumption Analysis.
attributes.description:
•    We evaluated the generator's fuel consumption from May 1, 2025, to May 31 2025, to assess its efficiency and ensure it operated within expected parameters.
•    Based on the collected data, the results were deemed reasonable and consistent with the operational standards for this period as seen below;
attributes.recommendation: •    The existing controls are effective and should be strengthened to ensure fuel consumption remains within reasonable limits and that the physical fuel balance is accurately recorded.
attributes.effect: •    The minor variance between the manager’s records and the system records suggests slight inconsistencies, which could be due to calibration issues or recording errors.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Slight variance in recorded vs. actual consumption 
Remediation Plan:

  • Calibrate generator meters for accuracy.
  • Use daily logs to reconcile system and manual records.

value: •    Calibration issue shall be raised for KAF to rectify.

•    Manager advised to raise ticket for calibration with K.A.F.
•    So will follow up to sort out issue
•    In the previous audit, analysis was done on the generator fuel consumption for a period of 40 days from 1st March 25 to 9th April 2025 which revealed a consumption of 21.27 liters/hour.
A reconciliation of generator usage hours and fuel consumption for May 2025 was done. The comparison between manager logs and system records aimed to detect anomalies or inefficiencies.
A slight variance was observed between the two records. Though minor, it points to a need for calibration and improved accuracy in generator monitoring systems.
Operations/Production Department
To verify the accuracy of generator fuel consumption records and ensure usage remains within operational norms.
